nodes.text: Teacher test-score value-added (VA) measures reflect teacher quality and higher VA teachers causally improve students long-term outcomes (college attendance, college quality, adult earnings, reduced teenage births, better neighborhoods, higher retirement savings)
We link administrative school records (grades 3–8, 1989–2009) to US tax records (1996–2011) for about 1.1 million students to measure adult outcomes and construct analysis dataset

Two empirical designs used: (A) cross-classroom comparisons conditioning on rich observables (selection-on-observables) and (B) quasi-experimental teacher turnover design comparing adjacent cohorts within school-grade

Identification assumptions: (i) forecast-unbiasedness of leave-year-out VA estimates; (ii) selection-on-observables for cross-class design; (iii) teacher-switching orthogonal to cohort shocks for quasi-experiment

Cross-classroom OLS estimates: a one standard deviation increase in a single-grade teacher VA raises college attendance at age 20 by 0.82 percentage points (mean 37%) and increases college quality by $299 on average

Quasi-experimental teacher turnover estimates: a one standard deviation improvement in mean teacher VA across cohorts raises college attendance at age 20 by 0.86 percentage points and raises college quality by about $198, supporting causal interpretation

Earnings impacts (cross-class design): a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by about 1.3–1.65% (baseline 1.34% used), implying discounted present-value lifetime income gains ≈ $7,000 per student (age 12) and undiscounted ≈ $39,000

Additional adult outcomes: a one SD increase in teacher VA reduces probability of teenage birth (~0.6 percentage points), increases neighborhood SES (percent college grads) by ~0.25 pp, and raises 401(k) participation by ~0.55 pp

Test-score impacts fade rapidly in subsequent grades (to ~25% of initial impact after 3–4 years) but long-run adult impacts re-emerge, consistent with 'fadeout and re-emergence' pattern seen in early childhood interventions

Heterogeneity: impacts slightly larger for females; English teacher VA yields larger long-term impacts than math VA per unit test-score gain; impacts roughly constant in percentage terms across parental income (higher-income families have larger absolute gains)

Policy simulations: replacing a teacher in the bottom 5% of true VA with an average teacher would raise present value of students' lifetime income by approx. $14,500 per student or $407,000 per classroom; selecting on estimated VA with 3 years of data yields about $185,000–$266,000 per classroom depending on assumptions due to estimation noise and drift

Cost-effectiveness: deselecting low-VA teachers appears far more cost-effective than paying bonuses to retain high-VA teachers because most high-VA teachers would remain without bonuses; estimated compensation cost to offset deselection risk small relative to projected gains

Limitations and caveats: VA predicts only the component of long-term impacts correlated with test scores (lower bound for earnings VA), potential bias if VA used for high-stakes evaluation induces cheating/teaching-to-test, drift and estimation error reduce predictive power, and inability here to identify structural interactions across grades or fully net out all other inputs

Overall conclusion: test-score based VA measures are informative proxies for teachers' long-term impacts and improving teacher quality (via deselection or other policies) can generate large social and economic returns, but implementation should consider potential behavioral responses and complement VA with other measures
